What can you tell me about wine?
responses: Wine is an alcoholic beverage, usually ranging from 10% - 20% alcohol in each bottle. After the fermentation process, it is essentially fermented grape juice. Wine can be both expensive and cheap, it all depends on the year it's made, the grapes it's made from, and where it's from. You have red wine, white wine, orange wine, rose wine and sparkly wine. Wine goes excellently with different types of food.

The difference with red wine in contrast to white wine is that the skin of the wine is included in the fermentation process. This process is called 'maceration' and is responsible for extracting the colour and flavour of the wine. The longer the skin is included in the fermentation process dictates how strong the wine is, as well as how transparent it is. Red wine goes well with meaty dishes that has fat in them, as it flushes out the taste of the meat if you drink some red wine after eating meat.

White wine is clear in colour and quite transparent. In general, the skin of the grapes is not included in the fermentation process, which means the colour comes mostly from the fermented grape juice. Many white wines are actually made from red grapes, a style known as 'blanc de noir'. White wine usually goes well with dishes that do not have fat in them, such as chicken or fish.

Orange wine is special in the way that it's made like red wine, where the skin is included, but the grape juice is made from white grapes. This is why orange wine has more of an orange tint to it's colour. Orange wine goes well with bold dishes such as curry dishes or Moroccan cuisine.

Rose wine is similar to red wine in the sense that the skin is included in the fermentation process, but not long enough to be considered a red wine. It is possibly the oldest known wine to be made, as the skin contact method is the most straightforward. Rose wine pairs up well with dishes such as chicken salad or spinach tartelettes.

Sparkly wine is otherwise known as the party wine, is wine with carbon dioxide in it, which makes it fizzy. There are mainly two ways to make it, the first is the traditional method which is natural fermentation in a large tank that can withstand high pressure over a long period of time. The other method is to simply inject carbon dioxide in the wine, which is more commonly found in cheaper sparkling wines.

Theoretically, the way you're supposed to taste wine is to first swirl your wine in your glass around to oxidize it a bit. Then, you smell the wine around the edge of your glass. Continuing onwards, you take a small and quick sip to get a general taste of the wine. Afterwards, flush your mouth out with water before taking a bigger sip and swirling it around above specific parts of your tongue, so that you use every taste bud to taste each different property of the wine.
